awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Novel Terahertz Generators Based on Magnetic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Generators of electromagnetic waves with frequencies near one terahertz are needed for several types of practically useful applications such as new bio-medical imaging techniques, highly sensitive chemical sensors and energy-efficient wireless computer chips. Existing generators of terahertz radiation have significant deficiencies that severely limit their usefulness. These generators either work at temperatures below room temperature or are based on expensive and bulky laser systems. The goal of this project is to create a new type of terahertz generator that is compact, inexpensive and works at room temperature. These generators are based on readily available magnetic materials such as iron oxide and nickel oxide and will operate via conversion of magnetic oscillations in these materials into terahertz electromagnetic waves. The goal of the proposed research program will be achieved via a collaborative effort of a synergistic team of experts in magnetic device fabrication (University of California, Irvine) and leading theorists in the field of magnetic devices (Oakland University).   The results of the proposed research program will impact society in multiple ways. The new method of terahertz signal generation will help maintain the US leadership in terahertz technology. A number of undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in modern device fabrication techniques, which will enhance the US nanotechnology workforce. The outreach activities, including demonstrations on magnetism and superconductivity, will target middle school students from underrepresented groups, and will help attract minorities to science and engineering.


The proposed research program is based on a substantial preliminary experimental and theoretical work of the proposers, who experimentally demonstrated spin pumping in Pt/hematite bi-layers, and theoretically predicted that a bi-layer of a heavy metal (Pt) and an antiferromagnetic material with strong easy-plane and weak easy-axis magnetic anisotropies can function as a source of coherent THz radiation when direct current is applied to the Pt layer. In such antiferromagnet-based auto-oscillators, an electric current in the Pt layer injects pure spin Hall current into the antiferromagnet and drives its order parameter into a state of persistent precession. This precession excited by the component of spin current perpendicular to the easy plane anisotropy of the antiferromagnet is non-uniform in time due to the weak easy-axis magnetic anisotropy present within the easy plane anisotropy. The frequency of the antiferromagnetic order parameter oscillations is proportional to the injected spin current, and increases from approximately 0.1 THz to 2.0 THz with increasing current density in the Pt layer. The order parameter oscillations are converted into a THz electromagnetic signal with electric field amplitude exceeding 1 V/cm via spin pumping and the inverse spin-Hall effect in the Pt layer. The dynamics of the THz-frequency room-temperature antiferromagnetic auto-oscillator is mathematically equivalent to that of a Josephson junction auto-oscillator, with the energy of the weak uniaxial magnetic anisotropy of the antiferromagnet playing the role of the Josephson energy. The demonstration of these compact, tunable and structurally simple antiferromagnet-based sources of THz radiation will enable the development of compact and inexpensive solid state THz devices for imaging, chemical detection, wireless chip-to-chip communication and THz spectroscopy/microscopy.

Overview:     

    The main goal of the Oakland University group in the research program supported by the NSF grant ECCS-1708982 was to develop a theory of a new class of compact and tunable THz frequency generators based on magnetic auto-oscillations driven by pure spin currents in bi-layers of antiferromagnetic insulators (AFM) and heavy metals. These THz-frequency antiferromagnetic auto-oscillators (AFM AO) were supposed to operate at room temperature and would not require external magnetic field.

     This theory was developed, and in the process of research it was found, that such current-driven AFM auto-oscillators in the sub-critical regime (before active generation) under the influence of an external prompt can work as generators of ultra-short (several picoseconds) spikes, performing the functions of artificial "neurons". Thus, the study of this "neuron"-like behavior of sub-critical AFM spike generators became an additional important goal of our research. It was found that artificial AFM ?neurons? can be used as elementary elements in a novel neuromorphic computer architecture that can very efficiently solve the problems like image recognition and classification.

    Another goal that appeared in the process of research was to develop a theory of a useful signal-processing device working at THz frequencies and based on AFM AO. The theoretical description of a THz-frequency spectrum analyzer based on a sweep-tuned AFM AO was also developed in this project.

 

Intellectual merit:

    Here are the main scientific outcomes of our project:

1. Canted antiferromagnets could be used in the  THz-frequency AFM AO, where the output signal is extracted using dipolar  radiation of a rotating net magnetization of the canted antiferromagnet. Main results were  published in the paper : O. R. Sulymenko et al.,  Phys. Rev. Applied 8, 064007 (2017) .

2. The effect of tunneling anisotropic magnetoresistance (TAMR) in an AFM tunnel junction can compete as a way of signal extraction from an AFM AO with the spin-Hall effect. Main results on this topic are published in the paper: O. R. Sulymenko et al., IEEE Magn.Lett., 9, 3104605 (2018).

3. An AFM AO, which in the super-critical regime works as a source of continuous THz-frequency signal, in a sub-critical regime could be a source of ultra-short spike pulses, if prompted by an additional current pulse. Thus, such an AFM AO can work as an ultra-fast  artificial "neuron", and the AFM artificial "neurons" can be used as building blocks for neuromorphic signal processing devices (see  R. Khymyn et al., Scientific Reports 8, 15727 (2018); O. R. Sulymenko et al., J. Appl. Phys. 124, 152115 (2018)).

4.  An AFM AO sweep-tuned by a linear driving current can be used as an ultra-fast spectrum analyzer on signals having frequencies between 0.1 THz and 10 THz and the power just exceeding the Johnson?Nyquist thermal noise floor. The main results on this topic are published in the paper : P. Yu. Artemchuk  et al., J. Appl. Phys. 127, 063905 (2020).

5.  Magnetic domain walls can be used as magnonic waveguides for on-chip control of the spatial extent and propagation of spin waves. We developed a method of generation of the spin waves  propagating in domain walles and having wavelengths between 1 μm and 150 nm, with excitation  frequencies ranging from 250 MHz to 3 GHz. The main results on this topic are published in : V. Sluka et al., Nature Nanotechnology (2019); https://doi.org/10.1038/ s41565-019-0383-4.

Broader impact:

     We firmly believe the theory of AFM AO developed in this research program will lead to the development of a novel class of THz-frequency AFM signal generators and signal processing devices, like spectrum analyzers based on the AFM AO. 

The students and postdoctoral fellows educated while participating in this research program will contribute to the development of a skilled workforce and informed public in the fields of nanoscience and nanotechnology, and will have a significant positive impact on our society in general, while helping to maintain the U.S. dominance in this critical area of technological research and development.

We also made a coordinated effort to reach a broader audience at the K-12 levels through participation in the job fairs at the Utica Community Schools. This program of school visits was aimed at attracting young students to future careers in science and technology.

We are  sure that the qualifications of our students trained in the process of this research in the most advanced methods of the modern theory of magnetism and experimental methods of nano-spintronics will help them make successful careers in science and technology.
